name: vifm
description: Ncurses-based file manager with vi-like keybindings

repo.name: vifm
repo.description: Vifm is a file manager with curses interface, which provides Vim-like environment for managing objects within file systems, extended with some useful ideas from mutt.

readme.summary: Excellent clarity and installation coverage with comprehensive resources, but lacks concrete usage examples and troubleshooting guidance in the README itself.
readme.top_issue: No inline code examples showing actual commands or workflows—users must navigate to external wiki/cheatsheet to understand basic operations like file navigation, copying, or moving files.

injection_risks.description: The function run_win_executable uses the win_exec_cmd function which may be vulnerable to command injection attacks if the input is not properly sanitized.
The function run_win_executable_as_evaluated uses the SHELLEXECUTEINFOW structure which may be vulnerable to command injection attacks if the input is not properly sanitized.

critical_findings: Potential command injection vulnerability in the run_win_executable function.
Lack of input validation for the full_path variable in the handle_file and run_win_executable functions.
security.summary: The code has some security concerns, including potential command injection vulnerabilities and lack of input validation, but overall it appears to be well-structured and follows good coding practices.

common_complaints: UI/UX enhancements (modal shadowing, scrollbars, window decorations)
FUSE mounting limitations and compatibility issues
Edge case bugs (chmod undo, file count in ruler)
sentiment.summary: vifm shows healthy community engagement with a mix of legitimate bug reports and feature requests, responsive maintainers closing issues, but lacking major architectural features like native archive support that users expect from orthodox file managers.

communication.summary: The maintainer provides detailed and helpful responses, but could improve in terms of patience and welcomingness towards new contributors.

concerns: No commits in past 6 months despite last commit being recent (2026-01-13)
136 open issues with no resolution activity
Zero closed issues in past 6 months indicating no maintenance
No merged PRs in past 6 months showing no active development
No active contributors in past 6 months
Unknown last release date suggests release information unavailable
positive_signals: Repository still exists and receives occasional updates
maintenance.summary: The vifm package shows signs of stagnation with no recent maintenance activity, unresolved issues, and no development contributions over the past 6 months despite a recent commit timestamp.

changelog.summary: The changelog is well-structured and comprehensive, but lacks explicit migration guides and has some complex technical details that may be hard for non-expert users to understand.

project_metrics.description: Vifm is a file manager with curses interface, which provides Vim-like environment for managing objects within file systems, extended with some useful ideas from mutt.

analysis_summary.doc_summary: The documentation is comprehensive but could be improved with more concise quick start instructions and troubleshooting guides.
concerns: relatively low number of closed issues
Docs: Lack of clear and detailed troubleshooting section
Security: Potential command injection vulnerability in the run_win_executable function.
Security: Lack of input validation for the full_path variable in the handle_file and run_win_executable functions.
Security: The function run_win_executable uses the win_exec_cmd function which may be vulnerable to command injection attacks if the input is not properly sanitized.
High bus factor risk (99% from top contributor)
highlights: frequent commits in the past 6 months
recent release within the last year
Breaking changes clearly marked in changelog
